awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a safe routing tool that uses multi-source data and associated data fusion to provide risk scoring based on real-time traffic, weather, and roadway conditions. With traffic crashes claiming 42,939 lives in the U.S. in 2021, integrating safer route analyses into navigation tools can revolutionize the mapping industry and enhance road safety. This technology not only serves as a tool for individual users seeking safer routes. Transportation authorities can leverage the technology and data for more effective road safety initiatives. Additionally, the adoption of this tool can incentivize safer driving behaviors, potentially leading to reduced insurance premiums, benefiting both users and insurance companies. Beyond its immediate impact, the project opens avenues for collaboration and knowledge-sharing among academic and research institutions.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a roadway risk scoring system for optimal route mapping. The technology integrates a safe system approach into route selection. The tool combines data from various historical and real-time sources related to road conditions, traffic, crashes, and weather. The solution employs a robust multi-source data fusion strategy to determine safety risks. In addition, the system employs advanced computer vision and artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms to generate real-time safety probability scores for different routes. This real-time evaluation marks a significant advancement in ensuring user safety, significantly improving the accuracy and reliability of the safety information provided to users. This information empowers users to make informed, data-driven decisions about their routes and travel plans and ensures that the tool offers a good understanding of potential hazards on various routes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Safe routing is a critical issue in transportation safety, with nearly 40,000 fatalities occurring annually on U.S. roads due to traffic crashes. Addressing this challenge requires innovative solutions that can help both transportation agencies and individual road users make safer travel decisions. Our project has actively engaged with a wide range of stakeholders—including state and local departments of transportation (DOTs), emergency responders, urban planners, and everyday commuters—to assess the need for a comprehensive safe routing tool. Through these discussions, we identified a significant demand for a system that not only accounts for real-time traffic conditions but also integrates crash risk predictions, road infrastructure safety, and historical crash data to provide optimal routing recommendations. This insight reinforced the urgency of our mission to develop an advanced routing system capable of reducing traffic-related fatalities and injuries.

To meet this need, we have developed an updated beta version of our online safe routing tool that leverages cutting-edge technology and high-quality open-source datasets. This latest iteration represents a major enhancement over previous models by incorporating more refined data layers, such as road geometry, historical crash hotspots, vehicle-pedestrian conflict zones, weather conditions, and traffic volume trends. These additional data sources have significantly improved the predictive accuracy of our routing algorithms, enabling users to make safer travel choices based on dynamic and real-time risk assessments. The integration of machine learning techniques allows the tool to continuously learn from new data, refining its risk predictions and ensuring that users receive the most reliable and updated route suggestions tailored to their specific needs. 

Given the overwhelmingly positive reception of our tool during stakeholder demonstrations and feedback sessions, we have set our sights on securing funding through the Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) grant. The SBIR program provides crucial support for technological innovation, and our proposal has already received a green light after a successful pitch. This grant will allow us to enhance the tool’s capabilities, particularly in expanding its dataset integration, improving scalability, and optimizing its dual-interface design. By incorporating additional data streams—such as connected vehicle data, real-time incident reports, and crowdsourced hazard alerts—we aim to provide even more precise and actionable insights. Additionally, the funding will support the deployment of a robust back-end infrastructure that ensures seamless real-time data processing, allowing for instantaneous rerouting and safety recommendations during dynamic road conditions.

The broader vision of this project is to create a transformative impact on road safety by making data-driven, risk-aware navigation an integral part of everyday travel. As we advance our efforts, we envision this tool becoming a standard resource for DOTs, emergency services, insurance companies, and individual users who prioritize safety in route planning. Beyond the U.S., our scalable framework holds potential for global adaptation, enabling safer mobility across different transportation networks. By securing the SBIR grant and continuing to refine our approach, we are committed to driving meaningful change in traffic safety, ultimately reducing roadway fatalities and fostering a future where safe routing is not just an option but a necessity.
